ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learnt a variety of new maths techniques.
Calculus level math and concepts

I learned how to expand on my previous math knowledge with a more concrete foundation. I was able to observe how proofs led to the theorems that we use to solve math problems, and apply them to real-life situations.
I developed problem solving skills and it was definitely useful in stretching me to think in terms of concepts rather than in terms of formulas.
Problem solving, using resources at school
I developed a critical understanding of the fundamentals of calculus. i.e. limits, how they apply to derivatives and it's application to some real life scenarios.

By taking this course, I have been able to understand the fundamental principles of calculus. Going into a math class this semester was daunting at first considering that I had not taken a math class for over a year, however, I felt that I was really able to take this class with ease. I believe that it will set the foundation for the different-level math courses in the future.
Antiderivatives
Learned much more on integrals and refined knowledge on limits and derivatives
I developed knowledge about problem-solving and self-advocacy.
I developed a further understanding of calculus and learned tofu dish alternative ways to solve problems
Good

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course can be improved by implementing more in class problems and discussions.

I liked the broad peer tutoring sessions that were offered most of the week. These were very helpful, and I went to them often. The Ximera assignments were very helpful as well. I do not have any suggestions for improvement.

The teaching of the course could definitely be improved. There were many lessons where I felt like I couldn't put my hand up to ask a question or people would think I was stupid. I also would have liked to have had more practice in class and done more worksheets myself so that i could see whether I understood.
Lectures are not engaging as there is no problems you get to try in class

This class teaches you how several concepts were derived which I think is very useful. However, for several weeks it felt more like a lecture, where the professor would just talk and the students would just listen. But getting to the end of the semester, the professor started giving ungraded in class try problems that made me feel more engaged in the class.

I believe that there could have been more ways that the class could have been engaging. Many times the chalk and chalkboard lecture was very unhelpful when trying to learn difficult math concepts. Moreover, I wish there was a way in which students had access to the information/material being taught before lecture.
Ximera is really helpful and most P-Sets are manageable even though some problems are very challenging

I feel like students with the head professor can be a little advantaged. 

A strength is the accessible office hours.
I think that more handouts would have helped. I also think going over some of the difficult problem set questions in class would have helped a lot.
Yes
I think they have a lot of stuff that they cover at the end of the course that they should have spent more time covering in the semester.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If they are interested in learning maths, it is a good course to teach you a variety of concepts.
Yes

I would recommend this course to another student. I believe even those with previous calculus background would benefit from taking this class. I feel well-prepared to tackle future calculus courses here at Yale.
I might, but it wasn't really a 'fun' course. Maybe I'm just not that into math...
Yes if needed for your major. Skip ahead if you are able to
Yes, I would. Especially if you have no or little knowledge about calculus.
Yes, I would recommend this course to other students. It sets the foundation and goes in depth to math concepts.
Yes, especially if you need it for fulfilling your pre requisits
Yes, good for those who took calculus but need reminders before moving on
Yeah, just to get a grasp on beginner calculus.
I would recommend this class to other if they had previous calculus experience.
Yes
For someone that just needs a math credit and is not touching the subject again, I'd recommend this class, but for someone who's looking to go forward with math I'd attempt to take 115.
